Award.AwardTitle: CI-ADDO-NEW: Collaborative Research: WiSER Dynamic Spectrum Access Platform and Infrastructure

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is aimed at the development and community release of a Wideband Software Extensible Radio (WiSER) platform along with a reference implementation for small outdoor deployment of a multi-node dynamic spectrum network. Dynamic spectrum technologies are strategically important to the wireless community because of the urgent need to alleviate spectrum congestion resulting from ongoing exponential growth in mobile data usage. While a great deal of theoretical work has already been done on dynamic spectrum techniques, definitive experimental evaluations of potential gains have yet to be conducted. The lack of experimental research is mainly due to the fact that available open platforms suitable for academic experimentation with software defined radio (SDR) are limited to first-generation technologies that operate at low bandwidth and can only handle a limited amount of MAC/PHY customization due to inherent processing constraints. The proposed WiSER platform is a second generation wideband open-source SDR platform that will enable new experimental research in the fields of dynamic spectrum and cognitive radio networking. The WiSER radio?s target release is timed to coincide with significant new national research and policy initiatives in dynamic spectrum involving the NSF, FCC, PCAST, NIST, DARPA and other agencies. This platform enables a richer range of experimental dynamic spectrum research than is currently possible because of its key technical features: operation across 400MHz-4000MHz in 125MHz increments, hardware acceleration for real-world PHY waveforms at speeds of 100 Mbps and higher, hardware virtualization capable of supporting multiple radios on the same platform, and an open-source software toolkit.

This project will develop a community resource supported by currently available radios along with an open-source software framework and reference system implementation. Such a resource will allow for research into a very scarce and important public resource ? radio spectrum. By improving reliable access to spectrum, our society benefits in terms of enhancing mobile broadband, improving public safety communications, and ensuring that radar and other spectrum uses are not degraded as the spectrum becomes more densely used. The WiSER team will work closely with experimental research groups nationally to help develop relevant and timely experimental deployments of dynamic spectrum technology. Dynamic spectrum access technology has the potential for order-of-magnitude improvement in spectrum efficiency necessary to cope with the recent explosion of mobile data traffic. Cognitive radio systems will also provide improved connectivity to end users, and enable new applications such as emergency response systems and automotive networks. This project will directly inform these important societal needs by enabling the research community to build state-of-the-art experimental systems for conclusive evaluation of these emerging technologies. Lastly, this platform will offer a powerful educational tool for students wanting to better understand modern digital and software-based radio communications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed and provided a community release of a Wideband Software Extensible Radio (WiSER) platform. Dynamic spectrum technologies are strategically important to the wireless community because of the urgent need to alleviate spectrum congestion resulting from ongoing exponential growth in mobile data usage. The WiSER platform is a second generation wideband open-source SDR platform that will enable new experimental research in the fields of dynamic spectrum and cognitive radio networking. This platform enables a richer range of experimental dynamic spectrum research than is currently possible because of its key technical features: operation across multiple physical layers using different radios (supporting both 400MHz-4000MHz in 125MHz increments and 40-6000MHz in 56MHz increments), hardware acceleration for real-world PHY waveforms at speeds of 100 Mbps and higher.

The developed hardware and software components were integrated and validated for an example wideband spectrum sensing application, demonstrating the feasibility and flexibility of the WiSER design.  As an independent validation, WiSER-based SDR units were successfully used to support spectrum measurement requirements in the DARPA spectrum challenge conducted on the ORBIT testbed during 2013 and 2014 using the system organization and dashboard shown in the attached figures. WiSER platform is also currently being used and further developed by two groups of external collaborators: CoreTex Lab in France and  NITLab in Greece. 

The project also developed a software system suitable for embedded SDR applications, including systems with reduced system weight and power. The WiSER Embedded system used the Zynq hybrid CPU & FPGA processor; a software framework was developed to use FPGA-based acceleration with high performance connectivity to the embedded CPU. This system was used fo a number of projects requiring low weight and power, such as deployment in quadcopter "drones" for spectrum enforcement and measurement campaigns to assess the feasibility of using the ATSC (Digital TV) signals for satellite navigation in lunar orbits. In this later study, a specialized enclosure was constructed (shown in the attached figure) that contained two software radio devices, GPS and interial tracking and data recording software. An FPGA-based correlator was developed to rapidly measure the ATSC signal. The dual-system device was launched in a weather balloon that reached 90,000 ft elevation (see attached figure) and operated purely on standard 5V USB batteries.

To simplify the use of the FPGA platform in the WiSER Embedded system, we developed an FPGA "Synthesis As A Service" system that simplifies the task of producing "bitfiles" for the FPGA accelerator. The system operates as a cloud-based web service that allows researchers to re-use existing FPGA components without needing extensive experience in FPGA design and development. The software organization for this is shown in the attached figure; the goal was to separate the design of the FPGA accelerator blocks from the packaging needed by users of those components.

Software and tutorials produced by this project is available at http://www.winlab.rutgers.edu/projects/wiser . The software for the WiSER Embedded platform has been published at:

  1. Host software environment for Zynq Zedboard & FMCOMS3 board - https://bitbucket.org/cusdr/cunoc_sdr
  2. FPGA based signal processing block repository - https://bitbucket.org/cusdr/cunoc_ip_lib
  3. “Synthesis as a service” component - https://github.com/dirkcgrunwald/wiserzynq-docker/wiki
